The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007, also known as the "Act", excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income, reducing the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. Qualified principal residence indebtedness refers to acquisition debt on the taxpayer's principal residence. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income, reducing the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. Exceptions apply for certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition, and an ordering rule is in place for discharged loans. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income. Coordination amendments prioritize principal residence exclusion over other provisions. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 prioritizes principal residence exclusion over other provisions for discharges of indebtedness on or after January 1, 2007. SEC. 3 extends the treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. The amendment applies to amounts paid or accrued after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 introduces alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 4 introduces alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation, including requirements related to gross income and property usage. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act, focusing on the expenditures of a cooperative housing corporation for the benefit of tenant-stockholders. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section excluding benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of any member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization, gross income shall not include qualified State and local tax benefits or qualified payments. Expenses incurred for services as a member will be taken into account for deductions under section 170. For qualified volunteer emergency response organization members, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits or payments. Expenses for services are deductible under section 170 only if they exceed excluded payments. Definitions for qualified state and local tax benefits and qualified payments are provided. The term 'qualified payment' refers to payments provided by a State or political division for services in a volunteer emergency response organization, with a maximum limit of $30 per month per taxpayer. A 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' is defined as any volunteer organization. The section outlines the requirements for a volunteer organization to provide firefighting or emergency medical services and be eligible for certain tax benefits. It specifies that the section does not apply after December 31, 2010. The section clarifies student housing eligibility for low-income housing credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with amendments applying to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The section addresses single parents and their children's eligibility for low-income housing credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment in section 7 applies to housing credit amounts allocated before or after the enactment date and buildings placed in service before or after that date, under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It also applies the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion to certain post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. The amendment in section 7 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 applies to post-marriage sales of property by surviving spouses within 2 years of their spouse's death, increasing the capital gains exclusion to $500,000. The amendment made by this section applies to sales or exchanges after December 31, 2007. SEC. 8. Modification of penalty for failure to file partnership returns; limitation on disclosure. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is increased from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to certain individuals is also amended. The amendment limits the disclosure of taxpayer identity information in partnership, S corporation, trust, or estate returns. The effective date of the amendment is the date of the enactment of the Act. The effective date for the limitations on disclosure of taxpayer identity information in certain returns is the date of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns. Penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 includes penalties for late filing or incomplete information, with a maximum penalty of 12 months unless reasonable cause is shown. The penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 is determined by multiplying $85 by the number of shareholders in the S corporation. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation and deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. The penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns is determined by multiplying $85 by the number of shareholders in the S corporation. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation and deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part I of subchapter B of chapter 68 of the Code. The penalty for failing to file S Corporation returns is $85 per shareholder. The penalty is imposed on the S corporation directly, and deficiency procedures do not apply. A clerical amendment is made to the tax code.
